job_title: Adjunct Professor in Woodland Park, NJ
pros: Great opportunity to teach multiple courses
cons: Only allowed to teach two courses per semester

job_title: Student Worker in Paterson, NJ
pros: Majority of co-workers were friendly.
cons: Spent the majority of my student work experience updating spreadsheets, running errands, calling and emailing students. Witnessed work place harassment by an individual in a high ranking position. Very unprofessional. Expensive education with mediocre work experience program. The future success of students seems to come second to school profits. A school advisor and co-worker through the student work program suggested that I use a credit card to pay for the remainder of my education when my Financial Aid had maxed out.

job_title: Campus Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Nice work environment. Friendly and pleasant
cons: They won’t keep you unless they have personal connections with you or knew you for years (remote)

review_title: employee morale at an all-time low
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Woodland Park, NJ
pros:
A Pro WAS there used to be funding for professional development opportunities. Now there are none. 
Another Pro was the great team of colleagues I have worked with. Now they have all left. 
A Pro was being able to have close connections with the students. There are barely any around on campus as they have preferred to stay online since the pandemic. Student facing staff is expected to be on mostly empty campuses while upper management works mostly all remote. It’s demoralizing.
cons:
Employee morale is at its absolute worst and no one seems to care about it !. For many years was a decent place to work, even though was always top heavy with highly paid VPs/executives and very low salaries for middle management/experienced professionals. There have been no salary raises in the past few years and even before the pandemic, a measly 1-2 percentage not taking into account cost of living and employee performance. 
Any complaints made to HR about toxic work environment, inequities or poor treatment of employees is brushed aside. the amount of layoffs and furloughs and those who have jumped ship on there own in the past two years is outstanding

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Newark, NJ
pros: comfortable environment, decent peers and management
cons: unstable due to low enrollments.

job_title: Programmer Analyst in Woodland Park, NJ
pros: Good place to work and grow
cons: None that I can think of.

job_title: Admissions Representative in New York, NY
pros: Overall the team in the adult dept is a good team, people all have the same goal and want to do well. Depending on who is the direct supervisor, the team overall is good.
cons: Over work you, upper management and the founders are very out of teach of the reality of the new world after covid. The expectations are very out of reach and no matter what the results are (which speaks for themselves) they cannot seem to accept that.

job_title: Assistant Director, Financial Aid in Woodland Park, NJ
pros: I learned a lot and met a lot of great valuable people.
cons: There is not much room for growth and there is a lot of favoritism when promotions are concerned. Communication is horrible from the top to the bottom. Yearly raises are minimal or non existent.

job_title: Professor in New York, NY
pros: Lots of free time to do research.

job_title: IT Business Analyst Systems Administrator in Woodland Park, NJ

job_title: IT Business Analyst Systems Administrator in Woodland Park, NJ

review_title: Full time and Adjunct Faculty Information you should know
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Woodland Park, NJ
pros: No Positives compared to other similar institutions
cons:
The below can be verified by reaching out to the human resources department at Berkeley Educational Services (BES)

Full-Time employees are treated worse than other staff in the college:
1. In 2020 received no raises, even though raises are less than cost of living increases when they are given
2. 2021 No mention of raises
3. Berkeley College stopped contributing to employee 401 k
4. Berkeley professors teach 5 classes compared to most other colleges only requiring 4 classes, with no additional compensation.
5. Berkeley professors are required to do vast amounts of non-course work with no additional compensation
6. The provost recently increased the workload further for all faculty with no increase in compensation
7. Other staff departments are constantly announcing promotions while the faculty are cut, have increased workloads, and no additional incentives.
8. In 2020 higher salaried employees had wages cut by the school.

As an adjunct, we are treated equally poorly:
1. Increased workload and vast amounts of extra work with no additional incentives.
2. Lower per-credit pay compared to other similar schools

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Everything! Benefits, salary, the people, raises.
cons: No Union but great place to work and respect for sure.

job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: Good location, close to public transportation.
cons: For profit school, only want to siphon off federal student loan money, students are given insufficient support, many drop out before graduating but are stuck with thousands in debt.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: The only pro is the paycheck.
cons: The students are 101% unprepared for college and the college is 101% pro student. The administration does not even care if you don't make it through your syllabus as long as all the students are walking out with A's and B's.

job_title: Admissions Representative in New York, NY

cons: Processes aren’t streamlined regarding collaborating with other departments. As a result, lots of hands are in the pot.

cons: Everything else. Compensation, students, depressing morale

review_title: I will never work for anything remotely similiar to this again
job_title: Admissions Associate in New York, NY
pros: I met some awesome people while working here and I loved connecting with the students. It was very rewarding to see them graduate even if it was with a sub-par degree. Most employees of Berkeley College know it's a joke.
cons:
Favoritism runs rampant throughout the college and management makes no attempts to hide it. They choose who they want to succeed and who they do not. They hire a lot of Berkeley graduates which is great for them.

Nobody wants to call HR in fear of getting caught.

Basically a call center, we are required to make a least 100 phone calls a day to leads/"prospective students" who the majority of the time hang up on us after they hear where we are calling from. Must convert phone calls into interviews. If a student wants a major we do not offer we have to persuade them to take up another major.

We are given enrollment goals and that is what they base your raise on.

job_title: Financial Aid Administrator in New York, NY
pros: great immediate team but you have to also take into account upper management and that can be unpredictable
cons: hard to move up and get raises

job_title: Interior Design in Paterson, NJ
pros: I love my job. Flexible schedule, great coworkers, fun environment.
cons: Working with students can be challenging at times

review_title: You Grow and learn as you help others
job_title: Peer Tutor in Woodland Park, NJ
pros: It is a great environment and you learn quite a lot from faculty members and from tutoring a variety of subjects. I tutored and studied in the same place which is very convenient for me.  Directors and Staff members are friendly and supportive.  It is empowering to be a role model for other students. It is rewarding in the sense that when you help others succeed, their success becomes yours.
cons: You must have a 3.00 and above GPA. It is a federal work-study position. So it is temporary.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: The students, staff, and majority of the faculty are the best thing the institution has going for it.
cons: The faculty is worked to death. There's too much stress and anxiety. It's not a healthy place to work. The full time faculty is run ragged and it never lets up.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in New York, NY
pros:
-certain level of flexibility of managing own tasks
-fair pay in comparison to majority of other colleges
cons:
-injustice of promotion of team leaders - lack of integrity
-race discrimination? - majority of team leaders are Spanish speakers
-focus on numbers than individual contributions

review_title: Scam- Overpriced- Poor Retention- Bad Administration
job_title: in Newark, NJ
pros:
-Clean Campus for the most part 
-Hourly Pay 
-Some nice students and faculty
cons:
-This place is ran like a business, not like a college
-We have to get a certain quota of bringing students into the school 
-It is totally overpriced and I almost felt guilty by bringing these people into this school because none of them could really afford it 
-What made me leave was the students, having to see some of them complain about money issues was just to heart breaking. 
-This school is a scam, we had to constantly put students in a revolving door to keep them into the school, to make money off of them I guess

job_title: Admissions Advisor in New York, NY
pros: Colleagues really love what they do and students are generally a pleasure to work with. Nice benefits and summer Fridays.
cons: Management are bullies and use snide comments and put-downs constantly to belittle their staff, going so far as to lie and blame others for their mistakes. Staff that have stayed only do so to keep good benefits and fear of not finding a job if they leave.

review_title: Berkeley College is the best place to work
job_title: Department Director in New York, NY
pros: Berkeley College is all about servicing students. I've worked here for 10 years and the professionalism, the high quality of work produced and the amazing entrepreneurial spirit make going to work a pleasure every day.  The College has been highly ranked in the Best Places to Work in both New Jersey and New York for 10 years straight.  We work hard and play hard and are appreciated for what we do.
cons: Communication could be better.  I’d like to know more about what’s happening on the other campuses.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Multi-campus college  in NY & NJ with job variety & flexibility. Good benefits! As a work community, HR sponsors  employee events that build work relationships and loyalty. I have had the pleasure to work with many bright, committed and caring professionals in Admissions.
cons: Company has grown so large and its structure remains  hierarchical.  For many years top leadership has been weak. There's a prevailing sense of job insecurity in this work community.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Paterson, NJ
pros: CIO and VP are leaders, they set the tone of the department. You will have access to the latest technology: software and hardware.  Great coworkers, management is approachable and supportive, plenty of training opportunities.  Goal oriented, fast paced, productive and encouraging environment.   If problems arise they are solved on the spot, just speak up.
cons: IS department is small once in awhile you will have a lot of stuff on your plate.  Learn time management skills and communicate proactively with stakeholders.

job_title: Chief Operating Officer in Newark, NJ
pros: Established institution in higher education; financially stable; great leadership team; cutting edge online program; great benefits and opportunities to grow and learn
cons: Family owned and parochial interest and mindset; small business school; fair customer satisfaction rating and average return on investment

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in New York, NY
pros: Flexible schedule, freedom to design syllabi, use of educational software
cons: Cannot rely on getting classes or the number of classes, teaching rates don't take into account the hours of work done outside of class, low pay in terms of the New York rate.

review_title: Theft of Student Loans, Bootleg University
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Salary, higher than most universities
cons: The students are horrible, can barely read/write/speak. Berkeley targets students that are not academically prepared for college, as a result you have to deal with students that are immature, rude, academically under-prepared, and unpolished. Work for this university and you will work long hours, deal with a lot of stress, be yelled at by students, be expected to make miracles for these students, and work a long with the worst professors that higher education has ever encountered. Not to mention working on Christmas eve, and New Years eve.

review_title: Not for Those Interested in Getting Ahead

pros: Good experience. Company executives are very interested in making money so they make money available for marketing, sales, placement, etc. to achieve their goals. This translates into many projects for employees and the ability to do many things and great experience.
cons: Salaries are low. Turnover is high. Cronyism is rampant. Meetings to discuss meetings.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Decent benefits, events for employees, like holiday party and volunteer opportunities.
cons: International area difficult environment to be in. Human Resources didn't care about abusive work place or high turnover. On a quarter system which means double the work but not pay.

review_title: If your in sales stay away from the woodland park location but overall not a bad place to outside of admissions.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY

cons: School is very expensive, extremely focus on only getting more student to start the next term. Very bad communication between all the Dept. specially Admission and Financial Aid. Retention is poor, graduation rate even lower

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in New York, NY
pros: Most campuses are very accessible by mass transit.
cons:
-Very unstable course load from term to term. One term you have 3 classes; the next none.
-The over all student enrollment is decreasing and classes are quickly cancelled as a result.  
-Adjunct faculty is under appreciated.
-Most students lack initiative or interest.
-The program directors set low student standards. In the short run this may benefit the student but in the long run they end up with a poor education.

job_title: Faculty in New York, NY
